title: ASX edges higher but Super Retail suffers
text:
BHP climbed 1.2 per cent to $35.39, South 32 jumped 6.6 per cent to $2.60 and Rio Tinto rose 1.5 per cent to $89.43 on Tuesday.

Low interest rates are likely to eventually start to flow through to more of the market, Mr Bundy said. Property-related sectors appear to be already "going quite well," he said, pointing to developer Mirvac's trading update out on Tuesday.

Mirvac said residential enquiries picked up over the September quarter in key home buying markets of Sydney and Melbourne. The firm reaffirmed its fiscal year profit growth prediction of between 3 per cent and 4 per cent. Shares slid 0.6 per cent to $3.15.

While property may have turned a corner, consumers are still holding back from spending.

"With little growth in income, high household debt, and, until recently, a cooling housing market, consumers have pulled back on their spending," noted HSBC's chief Australian economist Paul Bloxham.

Evidence of still-weak consumer spending patterns came on Tuesday from Super Retail, Shares dropped 8.6 per cent to $8.74 after it revealed that margins were damaged in the first 16 weeks of its new financial year as it slashed prices to tempt reluctant consumers into its stores. Comparable sales growth reached 3.2 per cent in the first 16 weeks of fiscal 2020 while total sales were up 4.2 per cent.

With little growth in income and high household debt, consumers have pulled back on their spending. — Paul Bloxham, chief Australian economist, HSBC

Advertisement

A raft of production updates from the commodity sector saw some companies rewarded but others punished.

Whitehaven rose 3.8 per cent to $3.28 after producing 4.4 tonnes million of coal during the September quarter and sticking to 2020 fiscal year guidance of coal production at 23.5 million tonnes and sales at 21 million tonnes.

Oil Search lost 1 per cent to $7.09 after third-quarter production volumes fell sharply on last year, with September quarter revenue and sales also declining as the energy producer revised down its full-year production guidance.

Lithium miner Orocobre declined 4.2 per cent to $2.27 after it posted a 10 per cent quarter-on-quarter decline in production for the three months to September to 3,093 tonnes which was still a September-quarter production record.

Independence Group's revenue rose 29 per cent to $236 million quarter-on-quarter. Underlying adjusted profit climbed 64 per cent to $154 million, Shares rose 2.6 per cent to $6.02.

Saracen, up 4.8 per cent to $3.53, reported record quarterly gold production of 96,324 ounces at an all-in sustaining production cost of $964 an ounce.

UK-focused banking group CYBG extended gains as investors continue to hope for an orderly solution to Britain's impending exit from the European Union, with shares up 9.6 per cent to $2.74.

Advertisement

"Market expectations [are ] that the risk of a hard Brexit on 31 October 2019 has diminished," said Commonwealth Bank foreign exchange strategists, in a reference to the potential for Britain to leave the EU without an exit deal.

Afterpay rose 1.9 per cent to $29.21. The regulatory risk surrounding the Reserve Bank's review of payments is manageable for Afterpay, said Morgan Stanley analysts, who believe the stock "looks oversold on misplaced concerns."

Ardent Leisure shot up 20.9 per cent to $1.215 after a buyer paid a significant premium for its shares, according to Street Talk.
description: Chinese buying of vast quantities of commodities and ultra-low interest rates are supporting the ASX, says Federation's Greg Bundy.
